titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Snowy, rainy weather. New Year’s Visits. Curious blunder of the Servant. Evening at the Princess Henry’s party. Could not play with her at Ombre. Played at Reversi with Madame de Haaren, M. Caillard, and the Marquis de Musquitz the Spanish Minister.— Court out of mourning for this day.
2. Weather similar to that of yesterday. Walk however about town before dinner. Evening reading as usual, having fortunately this day without engagement, which does not often happen.
3. Another day at my own disposal; and the last for a long time. Wrote Letters in the morning. Walk before dinner, and Evening spent in the customary reading.

4. Writing a little in the morning. Short walk before dinner. Evening and supper at Prince Ferdinand’s. Madame the Landgravine there. Prince Charles of Nassau (Weilbourg.) Other company not numerous. The Prince conversed with me sometime upon the subject of America. Enquired where Mr (Fitz) Morris) as he called him, meaning Gouverneur Morris is now. Said he had acted here more like an Englishman than an American; and had made a formal proposition from the British Government (from Pitt was his word) to this Court, to renew the War with the french Republic.— Played Whist, with Madame de Bredow, Generaland a Polish Count. Unruh. At Supper a Mademoiselle Obelgoue de Borck took the likeness of the Prince of Nassau with a pencil.— Shew me a book containing a number of likenesses which she has taken in the same manner; all of them extremely well done.— Home at about eleven.

5. Attended the ball this Evening at the Minister Baron de Heinitz’s. The king, Queen, and all the younger part of the royal family were there. The company very numerous. About twenty, or twenty five couples of dancers. The Queen danced all the time. the Ball began soon after 6 and was over between 9 and 10 according to the custom of the Country, where they universally keep very good hours.

6. Attended the Ball this Evening at the Minister Baron Alvensleben’s. The same company as that of last Evening; the king dances only the first dances. There is little real enjoyment, at such parties as these: they appear equally tedious to all the company. The associates are not well sorted. Respect on one side and condescension on the other, are not the ingredients of social pleasure. There is stiffness, coldness, formality, politeness, laboured affability, studied attention and every thing except that mutual abandon (to use a french phrase) which constitutes the charm of conviviality.

7. Walk with Mrs: A. in the morning. Dined at the Minister Struensee’s. Company consisted of about thirty persons. The Count de Schulenburg and his daughter Counts Wingersky, Zinzendorff, Molck Schleinitz, General Kunheim &c— The Minister is reputed to be a man of talents, and is apparently a man of business. At Court in the Evening. It was much crowded and most of the Princes were there— Home between 8 and 9.

8. M. de Maisonneuve called on me this morning and introduced me at the Cassino, a Society of which most of the foreign Ministers are Members, where all the newspapers are taken.— Walk with Mrs: A. and afterwards alone— Evening at the Princess Henry’s.— Reversi with Madam de Haaren, Madam de Lutzow and M. Caillard.

9. Dined at Mr: Schickler’s with a numerous company of Gentlemen.— Met there the Count de Gyldenstolpe, sent by the king of Sweden to compliment the present king upon his accession. Evening at Count Zinzendorff’s party. The last for the Season. Conversation with Lord Elgin. Home early. Mrs: A. unwell.

10. At the Casino this morning. Read the President’s speech at the opening of the session of Congress 23d. November. Ball in the Evening at Count Arnim’s. Grand Veneur & Minister of State. The king, queen and all the young Princes & Princesses there. Between two and three hundred persons dancing and at cards. Home before nine.— At Mr: Schickler’s this morning.
11. Mrs: A. unwell.— Walk round the town in the morning. At the Casino after dinner. Reading a number of newspapers. Evening at home; the first time for many days.

12. Another day at my own disposal— All the forenoon reading English newspapers. I am very much dissatisfied with the life that I lead. I can do little good, and obtain scarcely any information. At home all the after part of the day.

13. Walk before dinner with Mrs: A. and then alone. Evening at the Ball at Baron Alvensleben’s. These parties very much resemble one another, and the same company always attend them. Play’d whist with a General’s Lady, M. de Zastrow, the king’s first Aid de Camp & M. de Haagen. Home soon after nine.

14. Rainy and unpleasant weather. At Court this Evening to a ball and supper. The forms vary from those of a common Court. All the royal connections were there. Stay’d to make the bow to the Queen at supper: which M. Caillard says is necessary.— Caillard by the way, is remarkably civil to me. He is curious to find out what I am doing here.— Luckily there is nothing to discover. He took an opportunity, very adroitly to enquire, whether I write in cypher; and how I send my letters.— Whist with Madame de Lützow, Mlle: de Hagen, and a Count Molcke— M. de Maisonneuve told me that the Chevalier d’Araujo, had been arrested and confined in the Temple at Paris, notwithstanding his official character.

15. Wrote a little in the forenoon. Walk. Evening and supper at Prince Ferdinand’s, a party similar to the two former. The Princess Ferdinand very civil— Whist with a Countess Molcke, Count Neale and the Baron de Brentano, a Swedish Officer, who served in the french army during the American War. M. Caillard and his two Secretaries were there. He delivered a panegyric in favour of candour and frankness; said he had no finesse, but always went to work roundly and plainly.— “I am no Orator as Brutus is &c.” Mlle. de Borck took the likeness of the Swedish Count Steenbock; who she says has a Van Dyck head—
16. Newspapers and pamphlets from America.— Reading them all the morning.— Walk.— Rainy, dull weather— Afternoon and evening at home.

17. Reading over the Laws and Journals of Congress; of the last Session. Evening at a ball at the Count Podewils’s; the grand Marechal. The company the same as at the former balls, for they are all much alike. Conversation with the Comte de Callenberg, and with Monsr. de Sartoris, who enquired after Mr: Smith whom he formerly knew in Switzerland.— Evening not very bright.

18. Visit this morning from a Mr: Lutze; a merchant who wishes to be appointed Consul for the United States at Stettin.— I have no authority to appoint as I told him. He gave me a list of exports and imports at Stettin, and stated that he thought an advantageous commerce might be carried on directly between that Port and the United States. He is to see me again.— At the play in the Evening— Palmira Princess of Persia, a German translation of an Italian Opera. The scenery was magnificent. The music pretty good. The performers tolerable.— The house small, and very badly lighted. The royal box in front of the stage was full as it could hold. The king, queen, and all the younger part of the royal family were there. Upon the Queen’s entrance the company in the boxes rose, and she bowed complaisantly all round. No sort of notice was taken of the king when he came in, and he kept altogether at the hindmost part of the box.— Play over, before nine.

19. Called this forenoon to see Lord Elgin, who is very ill. Probably in a consumption. Walk afterwards about town— Day more industriously employed than usual, steadily writing in the forenoon. Evening at home; and this is a privilege, now so rare as renders it doubly precious.

20. Fine weather. Writing steadily— Walk. Ball in the Evening at Baron Alvensleben’s. M. Caillard introduced me to the Queen’s grande Gouvernante Madame de Voss, and to the Grand Marshall, Count Podewils.— Requested Madame the Marquise Parella, to introduce my wife to-morrow Evening at Court, which she accordingly agreed to do. We are to call upon her at 5; & Mrs: A. is to go and be presented first to Madame de Voss, who then presents her to the Queen.— The ball was dull.

21. Instead of 5. our Coachman made us wait till half past 6. When we arrived at Madam Parella’s, she was just gone to Court; we followed her immediately and arrived in Season for Mrs. A. to be presented to Madame de Voss, who presented her in a private Audience to the Queen. The Court was very much crowded. The king unwell, and very soon retired.— The ladies of foreign Ministers are invited to supper. The ministers themselves are not.— The Marquis Parella, therefore took a seat with me to go home, and the Ladies stayed to supper, and returned together.

22. At 5 this afternoon, Mrs: Adams went with the Marquise de Parella, and paid the usual visits to the Grandes Maitresses of the several Princesses belonging to the royal family. Sent round also the customary visiting cards.— Evening at the Princess Henry’s party.— Late there. Cards. Whist with three Ladies, of whom I knew only Madamoiselle de Voss Castel, daughter of the Queen’s Grande Gouvernante Madame de Voss.
23. Mrs: Adams went between 1 and 2 to have Audience of the Queen dowager, who received her very graciously.— The king is ill with the measles.— An hour at the Casino in the afternoon. Eveg: at home.

24. Reading du Page du Prat’s History of Louisiana, a very irregular, unmethodical, but not an unentertaining work.— Evening and supper with my wife and brother at Prince Ferdinand’s. Treated with great kindness and civility.— Whist with Madam de Buchholz. Count Neale & Count Wingersky. Upon returning home received letters from Mr: King and from America: they came by Lord Levison Gower, the English envoy sent to compliment the king upon his accession. Mr: Buchholz mentioned Littlepage to me who he says is yet at Warsaw. He says what I never heard before, and somewhat doubt, that Littlepage was the model from which Beaumarchais took his Cherubin in the Mariage de Figaro, and that the Comte & Comtesse Almaviva were taken from the Prince & Princess of Nassau.

25. Letters this day from Mr: Murray and from the bankers at Amsterdam.— Weather fine. Ball this Evening at the Countess Haack’s. Mrs: A. first out on these parties.— Whist with Madam de Wulknitz, the Countess Molcke (a great talker) and M. de Zastrow.— Conversation with M. de Musquitz the Spanish Minister, who does not like the assuming of the three coloured cockade by the Natchez. The king being ill neither he nor the Queen attended this Ball. The Princess of Orange also was absent from illness.
26. Letter this morning to Mr: King. Short walk. In the afternoon at the Casino. Evening again at home.

27. Letter to Mr: Murray. The mornings are scarcely long enough, for writing, and to allow me also to walk.— Weather fine and cold. Evening at Baron Alvensleben’s Ball: the last: though the Assembly to be still held next Saturday.— Introduced to Lord Levison Gower and Mr: Frere. The Ball rather dull. Home at 9.

28. Dined with Baron Schultz the Swedish Minister. Company small. Madam de Cray a Saxon Lady, and a wit. Conversation with the Baron after dinner.— Called at the beginning of the Evening at Madam de Voss’s, to enquire of the king’s health. Found there the Princess Ferdinand and the Landgrave her Sister. The Queen came in while I was there.— The king has the measles.

29. Wrote to the Secretary of the State in the morning. Walk with Mrs: A. The weather fine. Evening at the Princess Henry’s, to whom Mrs: Adams was first presented.— Played reversi with Madame de Parella, Madame Haagen, and Count Wingersky. Home at 9.

30. Ball this Evening at General Kunheim’s. There were more than five hundred persons present. The crowd excessive— It was the anniversary of the General’s birth day, he being 66 years old, and also of 50 years service in the army. There was a ceremony upon the occasion: a transparent picture, a burning altar: young girls to strew flowers and crown him with a garland, and a speech made to him by an officer in the name of his regiment.— Mrs: Adams danced.— Were obliged to stay till 12 o’clock.

31. Went this Evening to a party of Madam Eichstelt’s. Quite small in comparison with that of the last evening. Introduced to the Comte de Reden, a councillor in the department of the finances and of mines. conversation with him. Reversi with Madame de Parella, Madame de Haaren & M. Caillard.

Day. Rise between 7 and 8. Read till breakfast. Putter’s Germanic Constitution was followed by Champigny’s account of Louisiana; Du Page du Pratz’s history of Louisiana, which I am now bringing to a close.— Breakfast between 9 and 10. Write till 2. Walk from that till 3. dine. Dress for some ball or other Evening party. Between 6 and 7 go to it. Usually return home between 9 and 10. sup. And retire soon after ten.— I rise not early enough, because the Evening parties are too frequent. Of course read not enough.— If I can get an evening now & then to spend at home, read Geography or Poetry.
